B9 Procedural wings, works a charm :).

Some more, with little refinements here and there they're starting to look (and are performing) quite genuine. I can't wait to move onto other plane types though, like Bf 109s or P-51s.

My SU-27 

Can anyone help me on how to improve the maneuverability on this, not the most experience with <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr>. Id also like to know how to set <abbr title="Angle of Attack">AOA</abbr> properly on the front slats.

![bI18677.png](https://i.imgur.com/bI18677.png)

![4vSYTli.png](https://i.imgur.com/4vSYTli.png)

**Edited <time datetime="2018-02-07T18:59:56Z" title="02/07/2018 06:59  PM" data-short="6 yr">February 7, 2018</time> by SVS**

First make sure your control surfaces, and wing shape/surface are similar to the real thing:

![a5431318-105-Su27%20Top%20View%20-%20Air](https://static.rcgroups.net/forums/attachments/1/2/4/1/2/6/a5431318-105-Su27%20Top%20View%20-%20AirBrake.jpg?d=1357636338)

Also make sure you try and keep the proportions right (and thus the <abbr title="Center of Lift">CoL</abbr> vs <abbr title="Center of Mass">CoM</abbr>) because that's a key element. Also note how the wing root extensions are done and merging with the fuselage, and how they cover the intakes (which are not too far behind the cockpit actually).

I know first hand it's a lot of hours of work doing all that fine detail, but Sukhoi are into fine details that are kinda important to aerodynamics...

Once you have a really close model, you'll find out it's completely unstable and will flip over immediately. You need the AtmosphereAutopilot mod that simulates the fly by wire system of modern jets. Just set the limits in AA to decent realistic values, and you'll have an SU 27 that flies almost like the real thing ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif ":)")

(edit) from what i see in DCS (and i suppose it's like the real one) the edge slats are working in counter-<abbr title="Angle of Attack">AoA</abbr> mode.

**Edited <time datetime="2018-02-07T21:31:49Z" title="02/07/2018 09:31  PM" data-short="6 yr">February 7, 2018</time> by Surefoot**

> 
> 
> On 2/7/2018 at 1:54 PM, SVS said:
> 
> 
> My SU-27 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Can anyone help me on how to improve the maneuverability on this, not the most experience with <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr>. Id also like to know how to set <abbr title="Angle of Attack">AOA</abbr> properly on the front slats.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> [![bI18677.png](https://i.imgur.com/bI18677.png)](https://i.imgur.com/bI18677.png "Enlarge image")
> 
> 
> 
> 
> [![4vSYTli.png](https://i.imgur.com/4vSYTli.png)](https://i.imgur.com/4vSYTli.png "Enlarge image")
> 

I found for leading edge slats your settings should be between 3-6 deg no more than 7.  I have them set to <abbr title="Angle of Attack">AoA</abbr> not to roll, pitch, or yaw.

![ir0jTU6.jpg](https://i.imgur.com/ir0jTU6.jpg)

This craft is an older design of mine using AJE+<abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> and BDA.   You can actually see them deflected slightly in this pic.  

I started toying with the idea of slats a while ago, here is one of my early test fighters.

![xcoJf7b.jpg](https://i.imgur.com/xcoJf7b.jpg)

It had its drawbacks but did a good job of being a test platform for me, and actually lead to designs like this...

![SOMdLcm.jpg](https://i.imgur.com/SOMdLcm.jpg)

![G6sv4dm.jpg](https://i.imgur.com/G6sv4dm.jpg)

That is the same two craft, it has IR to move its wings forward into that position.

Okay, these are the very last Spitfire's I've made, I'll move onto the P-51 or Hurricane methinks.

Nice airplanes.

Yes, you will want forward surfaces with negative <abbr title="Angle of Attack">AoA</abbr> deflection, that creates a sort of artificial stability, which greatly improves turning performance.

[@MightyDarkStar](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/115126-mightydarkstar/) nice spits, they look really close to real ones.

Btw, you can use hispanos and brownings 303 on those spits, just get Aviator Arsenal and apply a module manager update pack.

Imgur

MiG-29

![eK0Er6I.jpg](https://i.imgur.com/eK0Er6I.jpg)

I just cant break through 333.4m/sec <abbr style="border-bottom:none;" title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> sees it as mach 1.093 but the <abbr title="Real Solar System (mod)">RSS</abbr>/<abbr title="Realism Overhaul (mod)">RO</abbr> RP-0/RP-1 contract to break sound barrier is 342m/sec ... so I'm short by 8.6m/sec. Doesnt seem to matter 500 meters, 1km, 5km, 10km, 15km all tested all the same, just over 333m/sec and then zip.

As noted this design is in <abbr title="Real Solar System (mod)">RSS</abbr> with <abbr title="Realism Overhaul (mod)">RO</abbr> with the RP-1 dev career 

WHAT AM I NOT DOING CORRECTLY? I think I'm area ruled correctly with the correct type of wing geometry, but now i need help lol. here are pics of what i have so far: 

[![TtNySIt.png](https://i.imgur.com/TtNySIt.png)](https://i.imgur.com/TtNySIt.png "Enlarge image")

[![cw4ftxj.png](https://i.imgur.com/cw4ftxj.png)](https://i.imgur.com/cw4ftxj.png "Enlarge image")

[![81aAcfj.png](https://i.imgur.com/81aAcfj.png)](https://i.imgur.com/81aAcfj.png "Enlarge image")

Nothing about the plane's design jumps out at me, at least nothing related to limitations to the craft's speed (dynamic stability is another story, but it's not what you're going after so I won't go there). You might have a tad too much wing inducing just enough drag. What does it look like when you've got the debug voxels turned on?  

Two other things - what are the stats on the engine you're using, and have you tried putting it into a steep dive (you know, climb up to about 20,000, then put her 30-40 degrees towards the ground with the throttle all the way to the stops)?

Here we go, it was the wing mass stopping me. Area ruling could be tweaked more, but it works.

[![02IhmG3.png](https://i.imgur.com/02IhmG3.png)](https://i.imgur.com/02IhmG3.png "Enlarge image")[![I71TBmZ.png](https://i.imgur.com/I71TBmZ.png)](https://i.imgur.com/I71TBmZ.png "Enlarge image")

[![CtESD10.png](https://i.imgur.com/CtESD10.png)](https://i.imgur.com/CtESD10.png "Enlarge image")

Even spalshes down full safely

[![AO6u4mV.png](https://i.imgur.com/AO6u4mV.png)](https://i.imgur.com/AO6u4mV.png "Enlarge image")

100 meters mach 1, ceilings, cruise 18.500 meters and zoom lift ceiling 20008 meters (then it spins out)

Even my U2 knock offs cant pass 20,000 meters, so I'm pretty happy

stats here: its a **Derwent V** 

#### 
Performance

- **Maximum [thrust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrust "Thrust"):** 2,000 lbf (8.90 kN) at 16,000 rpm at sea level, **Derwent V** 4,000 lbf (17.79 kN) at 15,000 rpm at sea level
- **[Overall pressure ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overall_pressure_ratio "Overall pressure ratio"):** 3.9:1
- **Turbine inlet temperature:** 1,560 °F (849 °C)
- **[Specific fuel consumption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrust_specific_fuel_consumption "Thrust specific fuel consumption"):** 1.17 lb/(lbf h) (119.25 kg/(kN h)), **Derwent V** 1.02 1.28 lb/(lbf h) (103.97 kg/(kN h))
- **[Thrust-to-weight ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrust-to-weight_ratio "Thrust-to-weight ratio"):** 2.04 lbf/lb (0.0199 kN/kg), **Derwent V** 3.226 1.724 lbf/lb (0.0316 kN/kg)
- **Military, static:** 2,000 lbf (8.90 kN) at 16,600 rpm at sea level, **Derwent V** 3,500 lbf (15.57 kN) at 14,600 rpm at sea level
- **Cruising, static:** 1,550 lbf (6.89 kN) at 15,400 rpm at sea level, **Derwent V** 3,000 lbf (13.34 kN) at 14,000 rpm at sea level
- **Idling, static:** 120 lbf (0.53 kN) at 5,500 rpm at sea level, **Derwent V** 120 lbf (0.53 kN) at 5,500 rpm at sea level

> 
> 
> On 26/03/2018 at 4:30 PM, Aazard said:
> 
> 
> Here we go, it was the wing mass stopping me. Area ruling could be tweaked more, but it works.
> 

The second version has more sweep & looks like less span, so also presumably overall less drag - you concentrated on wave drag, but compared to working on absolute overall drag that is a relatively small thing & you didn't give us any other numbers in the hangar. The static panel should tell you what you need to know, it'll have a cD figure for the <abbr title="Angle of Attack">AoA</abbr> at altitude.
